image.altText: A composite of images of a young and old Mick Doleman and a shipwreck under the ocean.

items.synopsis: The wreck of the Blythe Star is located almost 50 years after it sank off the Tasmanian coast, its crew believed dead — until, astonishingly, they appeared out of the bush far from where the ship sank.

title.children: The crew of the Blythe Star were thought lost at sea. So why did they stumble out of a forest?

image.altText: Roger Marshall standing in front of a hedge. He has slicked back grey hair and is wearing a sweater vest over a blue shirt.

items.synopsis: Queenslanders living in residential parks are experiencing housing stress due to unfair business practices, according to the state's peak body representing manufactured homeowners.

title.children: People living in residential parks say owners are causing housing stress due to unfair business practices

image.altText: Man wearing khaki clothing and binoculars around neck is surrounded by jungle-like trees

items.synopsis: The body of 69-year-old Christopher Gwin was found at his Sunshine Coast hinterland home on Saturday. A 68-year-old man has been charged with his alleged unprovoked stabbing murder.

title.children: Charges laid over alleged stabbing murder of 69yo Sunshine Coast man

image.altText: Sophie and Jasmina wearing white dresses with large pregnant bellies, smiling, garden behind.

items.synopsis: Michelle and Jono Harley always dreamed of having a family — their devastating fertility journey took a twist when relatives stepped in with an extraordinary back-up plan.

title.children: The grandma, the aunt and the extraordinary back-up plan that made two babies

image.altText: a close-up of a traffic light box, the red light is glowing

items.synopsis: The Queensland government will install more "Hold the Red" radars at targeted locations in the hope of reducing crashes caused by people running red lights.

title.children: Radars that detect red light-runners to be rolled out at crash-prone intersections

image.altText: An older white man in heavily armoured combat gear and a helmet stands on a rooftop, with a soldier looking out behind him.

items.synopsis: Today, as Russia's President Vladimir Putin flails around dispatching one failed military chief after another, Yevgeny Prigozhin — for the moment at least — is probably the safest Russian in the world, writes John Lyons in Kyiv.

title.children: Putin needs this man more than anyone else — until the moment he ceases to be of use

image.altText: an historic wartime poster depicting a burning sinking hospital ship that says 'avenge the nurses'

items.synopsis: As Dr Grace Xu battles to look after Queenslanders on the healthcare frontline, she's inspired by a legendary nurse whose hospital ship went down during World War II.

title.children: Families, fellow nurses pause to remember anniversary of the sinking of the Centaur

image.altText: An external shot of a zinc factory looking up towards a blue sky and white clouds.

items.synopsis: As South Korea edges closer to being solely powered by renewables come 2050, the manufacturing industries of Australia's third-largest trading partner believe hydrogen gas is the answer to help reach its target.

title.children: Korea's demand for Australian hydrogen has never been higher. Is it the start of a new mining boom?

image.altText: A line stretches back as far as the eye can see outside Centrelink.

items.synopsis: You can define a "recession" in different ways. Are we experiencing one now? asks Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: What is a recession? Are we experiencing one now?

image.altText: Sam kerr is mid-backflip with Chelsea teammates around her after a goal in the Women's FA Cup final.

items.synopsis: Sam Kerr scores her fifth goal from the past three FA Cup finals as Chelsea beats Manchester United 1-0 in front of more than 77,000 fans at Wembley.

title.children: Record crowd packs out Wembley to watch Sam Kerr win FA Cup for Chelsea

image.altText: Three mugshots of three separate men. The first has tattoos on his face. The second has a beard. The third has darker skin.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happened.

title.children: Manhunt for three escaped prisoners, and Paddington and the Queen win a BAFTA. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: A colourful abstract map, with hues ranging through a red to blue spectrum.

items.synopsis: Canberrans are sometimes accused of being out of touch and different from other Australians — and this socio-economic data shows they are.

title.children: The 'Canberra bubble' is very real. Here's the data that proves it

image.altText: Jason Day hugs his son as he walks off a golf course in the rain.

items.synopsis: Thirteen years after winning his maiden PGA Tour crown at the Byron Nelson, Australian Jason Day wins the Texas event again for his first victory since 2018 and 13th overall.

title.children: Jason Day ends five-year title drought at the site of his maiden triumph

image.altText: Recep Tayyip Erdogan looks down in front of a black background while standing next to the Turkish flag

items.synopsis: Türkiye appears headed for a run-off presidential election, with the parties of both Recep Tayyip Erdoğan and opposition rival Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu both claiming the lead.

title.children: Türkiye run-off election likely as both President Erdoğan​​​​​​​ and opposition leader claim lead

image.altText: A young Thai man in white shirt smiles and waves to camera with people taking photos around him.

items.synopsis: Thailand's opposition secured a stunning election outcome on Sunday, setting the stage for deal-making over the formation of a coalition government in a bid to end nearly a decade of military-backed rule.

title.children: Thailand's opposition parties dominate preliminary election results in challenge to army-backed government

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is set for a relatively flat start to the week after US stocks ended last week with a dip. Follow the latest on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set for fairly flat start amid more US recession worries, Newcrest backs Newmont takeover

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After a pursuit over the past few months, US gold giant Newmont appears to have landed its Australian target, with Newcrest's board agreeing to back its takeover offer. In the absence of a superior proposal emerging, Newcrest's board has unanimously supported the offer that will see its shareholders receive 0.4 Newmont shares for each Newcrest share they own. Newcrest can also pay its shareholder a special franked dividend of up to $US1.10 a share prior to completion of the deal. The Australian company says the deal values Newcrest at $29.27 per share, a 30.4% premium to prior to Newmont's initial offer being made. The deal values Newcrest at an enterprise value of $28.8 billion, leaving its shareholders with a 31 per cent stake in the combined company. Newcrest says it will leave the merged company as a "clear global leader in gold production" with a significant and growing presence in copper. Aside from needing support from Newcrest shareholders, the deal will also need regulatory approvals from the Foreign Investment Review Board and other regulators in several countries.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Newcrest board backs Newmont's latest takeover offer

children.content: After a pursuit over the past few months, US gold giant Newmont appears to have landed its Australian target, with Newcrest's board agreeing to back its takeover offer.
In the absence of a superior proposal emerging, Newcrest's board has unanimously supported the offer that will see its
shareholders receive 0.4 Newmont shares for each Newcrest share they own
Newcrest can also pay its shareholder
a special franked dividend of up to $US1.10 a share
prior to completion of the deal.
The Australian company says
the deal values Newcrest at $29.27 per share, a 30.4% premium
to prior to Newmont's initial offer being made.
The deal values
Newcrest at an enterprise value of $28.8 billion, leaving its shareholders with a 31 per cent stake
in the combined company.
Newcrest says it will leave the merged company as a "clear global leader in gold production" with a significant and growing presence in copper.
Aside from needing support from Newcrest shareholders, the deal will also need regulatory approvals from the Foreign Investment Review Board and other regulators in several countries.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While US markets finished with modest falls, there was a bit more action during the session. The US equivalent of the Westpac-Melbourne Institute consumer sentiment survey here showed that many Americans expect price increases to remain higher for longer. "Bond, currency and equity market were all spooked on Friday by the reported rise in the 5-10 year inflation expectations component of the University of Michigan's preliminary May Consumer Sentiment survey," noted NAB's head of FX strategy Ray Attrill. "It rose to 3.2% from 2.9% against an expected 3%, its highest reading since March 2011 (also 3.2%) and previously higher (3.4%) as far back as mid-2008 just prior to the GFC. "No matter that Consumer Sentiment itself slumped to 57.7 from 63.5, well below expectations. "The release sparked a 10 basis point jump in front-end US bond yields, a 0.5% rally in the DXY dollar index and near 1% fall in the S & P 500 (about half of which was subsequently retraced). "In the US money market, the release has sown a few seeds of doubts regarding confidence the Fed will pass on another rate rise next month, June Fed Funds pricing finishing Friday ascribing a 13% chance to another 25 basis point hike, up from less than 3% on Thursday." So consumers expect higher inflation, which could mean even higher interest rates. On the other hand, the performance of smaller companies (small caps) on the US share market has some analysts sharpening their predictions of a US recession within the next year. This from Lewis Krauskopf at Reuters : The small-cap Russell 2000 is down about 1% this year, compared to a rally that has boosted the S & P 500, an index representing the largest US companies, 7% year-to-date. Like the inverted U.S. Treasury yield curve and strength in gold prices, the weakness in shares of smaller companies — which tend to derive profits domestically and be more vulnerable to economic shifts than larger firms — is one of several signs that investors are uneasy about the economic outlook. Small cap stocks have struggled since turmoil in US regional banks erupted in early March, with the Russell 2000 down 7% since March 8. Investors fear that smaller firms will be hit hard by a potential lending slowdown that could weigh on the broader economy. Investors are "trying to position their portfolios for what they think is going to happen in the economy," said Eric Kuby, chief investment officer at North Star Investment Management, which specializes in small caps. "Small caps being out of favor is another signal that investors are bracing themselves for an impending recession." Small caps have tended to waver ahead of economic weakness in the past. Since 1980, the Russell 2000 has lagged the S & P 500 by an average of about four percentage points in the six months after the economic cycle has peaked, ahead of a recession, according to Strategas data. Economic data has so far shown few signs of a sharp drop-off in growth, though inflation and some other important metrics have cooled. Still, some market participants believe the Fed's 500 basis points of rate increases over the past year are only starting to impact the economy. "We are likely headed into a recession sometime in the next 12 months," said Michael Arone, chief investment strategist at State Street Global Advisors. "Typically in a recession, small caps underperform." So will the US have a recession, persistent inflation, or could it be both, in a phenomenon known as "stagflation"? My colleague Gareth Hutchens wrote some great pieces about this topic last year:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Inflation, recession … or both?

featuredLink.title: Stagflation was born in the 1970s, but is it about to make a 21st century comeback?

children.content: While US markets finished with modest falls, there was a bit more action during the session.
The US equivalent of the Westpac-Melbourne Institute consumer sentiment survey here showed that many Americans expect price increases to remain higher for longer.

"Bond, currency and equity market were all spooked on Friday by the reported rise in the 5-10 year inflation expectations component of the University of Michigan's preliminary May Consumer Sentiment survey," noted
NAB's head of FX strategy Ray Attrill
"It rose to 3.2% from 2.9% against an expected 3%, its highest reading since March 2011 (also 3.2%) and previously higher (3.4%) as far back as mid-2008 just prior to the GFC.
"No matter that
Consumer Sentiment itself slumped to 57.7 from 63.5
, well below expectations.
"The release sparked a 10 basis point jump in front-end US bond yields, a 0.5% rally in the DXY dollar index and near 1% fall in the S
P 500 (about half of which was subsequently retraced).

"In the US money market, the release has sown a few seeds of doubts regarding confidence the Fed will pass on another rate rise next month, June Fed Funds pricing finishing Friday ascribing a 13% chance to another 25 basis point hike, up from less than 3% on Thursday."
So consumers expect higher inflation, which could mean even higher interest rates.
On the other hand, the performance of smaller companies (small caps) on the US share market has some analysts sharpening their predictions of a US recession within the next year.
This from
Lewis Krauskopf at Reuters
The small-cap Russell 2000 is down about 1% this year, compared to a rally that has boosted the S
P 500, an index representing the largest US companies, 7% year-to-date.

Like the inverted U.S. Treasury yield curve and strength in gold prices, the weakness in shares of smaller companies — which tend to derive profits domestically and be more vulnerable to economic shifts than larger firms — is one of several signs that investors are uneasy about the economic outlook.

Small cap stocks have struggled since turmoil in US regional banks erupted in early March, with the Russell 2000 down 7% since March 8. Investors fear that smaller firms will be hit hard by a potential lending slowdown that could weigh on the broader economy.

Investors are "trying to position their portfolios for what they think is going to happen in the economy," said Eric Kuby, chief investment officer at North Star Investment Management, which specializes in small caps.
"Small caps being out of favor is another signal that investors are bracing themselves for an impending recession."
Small caps have tended to waver ahead of economic weakness in the past.
Since 1980, the Russell 2000 has lagged the S
P 500 by an average of about four percentage points in the six months after the economic cycle has peaked, ahead of a recession, according to Strategas data.

Economic data has so far shown few signs of a sharp drop-off in growth, though inflation and some other important metrics have cooled. Still, some market participants believe the Fed's 500 basis points of rate increases over the past year are only starting to impact the economy.
"We are likely headed into a recession sometime in the next 12 months," said Michael Arone, chief investment strategist at State Street Global Advisors.
"Typically in a recession, small caps underperform."
So will the US have a recession, persistent inflation, or could it be both, in a phenomenon known as "stagflation"?
My colleague
Gareth Hutchens
wrote some great pieces about this topic last year:

image.altText: Light streaks at night are seen behind a white cross beside a road.

items.synopsis: Independent monitoring of the national road toll finds deaths on Australia's roads have risen in almost every state and territory, prompting concerns the National Road Safety Strategy is failing.

title.children: 'Difficult to understand': Road toll rises in almost every state and territory

image.altText: Light shines through a window onto a man wearing a blue jumper and glasses.

items.synopsis: Residents in a riverside retirement village that flooded last October, extensively damaging dozens of homes, say they were staggered to learn the village had a limit of $5 million for flood insurance.

title.children: 'We built on a swamp': Flood insurance at disaster-struck retirement village had $5 million limit

image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese and Linda Burney in front of the Uluru Statement

items.synopsis: What is it, how will it work and who's for and against it? We break down everything to do with the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: We keep hearing about a Voice to Parliament. What is it and how would it work?

image.altText: A rescue boat in the water with at least four people on board.

items.synopsis: A man has died and two other people have been treated for hypothermia after spending four hours in the water off the West Australian coast.

title.children: One dead, two rescued after boat accident off Geraldton coast

image.altText: Lara Alexander wears a black coat and blue and pink scarf and stands on a suburban Launceston street

items.synopsis: Newly-independent MP Lara Alexander says a "huge weight" has been lifted from her shoulders, while the Tasmanian Greens' push to axe Hobart's new stadium look set for failure without Labor's support.

title.children: 'A huge weight lifted': MP relieved after becoming an independent, but headaches ahead for now-minority government

image.altText: Zoe Bettison standing behind five microphones talking

items.synopsis: For governments, social media influencers have become a communication frontline particularly as they try to connect with young people. But evaluating the success of such strategies is hard to do, writes Rory McClaren.

title.children: Influencers, TikTok and taxpayer dollars: The world of tourism marketing in the social media age

image.altText: Person leaning over a table wearing a hooded gown, with a box of tissues and a mug on the table.

items.synopsis: This respiratory virus is so common that most children will have had at least one infection before they turn two. Most cases are mild, but it can cause severe illness for young children, the elderly and the immunocompromised.

title.children: Australia has been counting RSV cases for less than two years. Here are the basics about the common cold virus

image.altText: A woman and a man near Ayers Rock in Northern territory.

items.synopsis: A Queensland woman last seen on South Australia's western Eyre Peninsula a week ago is found by a member of the public who saw her "wandering out of the scrub". Her family say she's now recovering in hospital.

title.children: 'I just broke down': Family's relief as Queensland woman found a week after going missing in SA town

image.altText: Jim gestures as he speaks at a podium.

items.synopsis: Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers has refused to rule out the Coalition's proposal to increase the JobSeeker income free threshold, but Social Services Minister Amanda Rishworth has dismissed it as a "thought bubble with no substantive analysis behind it".

title.children: Peter Dutton proposal has 'no substantive analysis behind it' but Jim Chalmers refuses to rule it out

image.altText: Ron DeSantis greets audience members during a fundraising picnic for U.S. Rep. Randy Feenstra

items.synopsis: Decrying a "culture of losing," Florida Governor Ron DeSantis tries to weaken Donald Trump's grip on the Republican Party in Iowa after the former president is forced to cancel a rally in the battleground state due to a hurricane warning.

title.children: 'A culture of losing': Ron DeSantis blames Donald Trump for GOP woes during Iowa rally

image.altText: French Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne standing next to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in front of a French plane.

items.synopsis: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says Ukraine is preparing a counteroffensive designed to liberate areas occupied by Russia, not to attack Russian territory, while two Russian commanders are killed in fighting near Bakhmut.

title.children: Zelenskyy makes surprise visit to Paris for talks on Ukraine's urgent needs

image.altText: Bernard Arnault stands between his two oldest children

items.synopsis: When the world's richest person sits down for monthly lunches in Paris with his five children, he's searching for his successor. Welcome to the house of Arnault.

title.children: He's called the 'wolf in cashmere'. Now the world's richest man needs to pick a child to succeed him

image.altText: Women hold children and walk on flooded streets while drenched by rain.

items.synopsis: A powerful cyclone has killed at least three people and caused substantial damage in Myanmar, but so far it has spared the densely populated refugee camps in neighbouring Bangladesh.

title.children: Deadly Cyclone Mocha hits Myanmar and Bangladesh coasts
